The moon shone bright — I stray'd along,</br>Where Thames so sweetly flows,</br>And oft I rais'd the rustic song,</br>Impell'd by fancied woes.
I sung of love, and all its charms,</br>Of love with scorn repaid,</br>I sung of jealousy's alarms,</br>And blam'd th' inconstant maid.
"Farewell, I cried, ye giddy train,</br>So fickle and untrue,</br>And heav'n protect that hapless swain,</br>Who builds his hopes on you.
"These hopes, alas!  will quickly fly,</br>Nor leave a shade behind,</br>And cold disdain shall arm that eye,</br>Which lately beam'd so kind.
"Yet to that slighted youth, the Spring</br>Smiles chearfully in vain,</br>And tho' the Linnets sweetly sing,</br>They cannot ease his pain."—
Thus flow'd my strain, as fancy bade,</br>I thought no mortal nigh—</br>I turn'd me to the sylvan shade,</br>A stranger caught my eye.
Grief mark'd his face, his locks were grey,</br>An ancient harp he bore,</br>And plain and rude was his array,</br>As that which Druids wore.
"Mortal, he said, thy cares are vain,</br>Such cares thou must forego;</br>It ill becomes thee to complain,</br>Or grieve at fancied woe.
"If grief you love, come follow me,</br>And where yon elms appear,</br>A mournful monument you'll see</br>That justly claims a tear.
"That monument the DRUIDS rais'd,</br>It bears a Poet's name,</br>Whom Britain's children long have prais'd,</br>A fav'rite son of fame.
"Oft have we seen him on these plains,</br>(He lov'd the calm retreat)</br>Oft have we heard his polish'd strains,</br>And every note was sweet.
"Say, Nature say, for thou canst tell,</br>Are not the words thy own,</br>When to the hermit's peaceful cell—</br>The poet leads us on.
"Do not thy thoughts appear,</br>Does not thy voice adorn,</br>When these sweet sounds salute the ear,</br>'Turn, gentle hermit, turn.'
"O!  say what beauties grace the song,</br>What heavenly Ardor warms,</br>When ANGELINA, lost so long,</br>Is lock'd in EDWIN'S arms.
"This strain the Druids oft repeat</br>In some sequester'd grove,</br>Where with the Fairy train they met,</br>To hear the tales of love.
"For still the Druids haunt this isle,</br>And fairies oft are seen,</br>When sleep rewards the plowman's toil,</br>And shepherds leave the green.
"Oft hand in hand, in mirthful mood,</br>At night we tread the lawn,</br>And hide us in this lonely wood,</br>When day begins to dawn.
"And here with some bewitching strain,</br>We cheat the ling'ring hours,</br>Till the pale moon returns again,</br>And makes all nature ours.
"And oft in hearing GOLDSMITH'S lays,</br>These lays that touch the soul,</br>We've pass'd the longest Summer days,</br>And wonder'd how they stole.
"But ah!  these strains we'll hear no more,</br>For to yon darksome dell,</br>This morn the weeping shepherds bore,</br>The bard we lov'd so well:
"With decent grace we saw them bend,</br>And lay in yonder grave,</br>The friend of man, the muse's friend,</br>Whom virtue could not save.
"And can we stay when he is gone?</br>Can we enjoy these plains?</br>Ah!  no, their sweetest charms are flown,</br>They've lost their poet's strains.—
"Auburn farewell — no more we'll stray</br>'Mid thy deserted bow'rs,</br>T' applaud thy poet's plaintive lay,</br>And pluck thy withering flow'rs.
"No more the Druids shall appear,</br>But like thy hapless train,</br>Drop, as they pass, a silent tear,</br>And seek some happier plain.
"Yet on that plain, where'er it is,</br>We'll oft together join,</br>And fondly tell the scenes of bliss</br>The joys that once were thine.
"Ev'n there we'll crown thy bard with bays,</br>And give him just applause,</br>When we recall his pleasing lays,</br>And think what Auburn was.
"Perhaps where Alpine hills ascend,</br>We'll sit us down at last,</br>And see fair ITALY extend,</br>And think of pleasures past;
"Then turning, trace the various scenes</br>Where GOLDSMITH'S pencil drew,</br>And own, with tears, that all his strains</br>Are just, are strictly true.
"Yet ere we left our native land,</br>We rais'd this sacred stone,</br>Where SCULPTURE, with an artful hand,</br>The poet's worth hath shown.
"Then turn and read — nor rail at love,</br>Nor drop that useless tear,</br>Nor let unreal sorrow move,</br>But pay a tribute here."
I turned, I read, I heav'd a sigh,</br>My conduct who can blame,</br>For every bard that passes by</br>Will always do the same.

THE INSCRIPTION.</br>"Adieu sweet bard, to each fine feeling true,</br>Thy virtues many, and thy foibles few,</br>Those form'd to charm, ev'n vicious minds, and these</br>With harmless mirth the social soul to please,</br>Another's woe thy heart could always melt,</br>None give more free, for none more deeply felt.</br>Sweet bard adieu, thy own harmonious lays</br>Have sculptur'd out thy monument of praise.</br>Yes — these survive to time's remotest day,</br>While drops the bust, and boastful tombs decay.—</br>Reader, if number'd in the muse's train,</br>Go tune the lyre, and imitate his strain;</br>But, if no poet thou, reverse the plan,</br>Depart in peace, and imitate the man."</br>
